title: Algolsheim
text:
Algolsheim () is a <a href="Communes%20of%20France">commune</a> in the <a href="Haut-Rhin">Haut-Rhin</a> <a href="Departments%20of%20France">department</a> in <a href="Grand%20Est">Grand Est</a> in north-eastern <a href="France">France</a>.
Geography.
This Alsatian commune is located in the <a href="Haut-Rhin">Haut-Rhin</a> (68) several kilometers from <a href="Neuf-Brisach">Neuf-Brisach</a>.
Situated from the border with <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, Algolsheim includes a good number of <a href="Germany">German</a> residents, which has considerably increased its number of inhabitants in recent years. Algolsheim is part of the <a href="Canton%20of%20Ensisheim">Canton of Ensisheim</a> and the <a href="Arrondissement%20of%20Colmar-Ribeauvill%C3%A9">Arrondissement of Colmar-Ribeauvillé</a>.
History.
In 1196, the village was mentioned under the name d'Altolvisherde. From 1324 until the <a href="French%20Revolution">Revolution</a>, the commune was part of the holdings of the counts of <a href="Wurtemberg">Wurtemberg</a>. Between 1870 and 1875, several <a href="tomb">tomb</a>s of <a href="bronze">bronze</a> were found in the territory of the commune. The village then held the name Alt-Olsheim. It owes its current name to the ease with which it can be confused with that of <a href="Andolsheim">Andolsheim</a>. The town includes a <a href="Catholicism">catholic</a> church, a <a href="protestant">protestant</a> temple since 1864, as well as a <a href="Mennonite">Mennonite</a> chapel founded in 1977. Modernised <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>, the principal industry of Algolsheim, maintains a healthy level, despite the increasing scarcity of farmers. More than half of the inhabitants of the commune work in the nearby industrial centers on the banks of the <a href="Rhine">Rhine</a>. The construction of new housing projects has led to an increase in the demographic diversity of the village. Algolsheim possesses a rich natural heritage, owing to the proximity of the Rhine <a href="forest">forest</a> and the île du Rhin.
